hedline.hl1: Pulled Off the Air, Conservatives' Ad Returns on the Web

abstract.p: Conservative Party pulls from airwaves commercial assailing Hillary Rodham Clinton on health care; keeps ad on party's Web site, saying it does not violate soft money ban (M)

block.p: The Conservative Party may have pulled from the airwaves an ad assailing Hillary Rodham Clinton on health care, but the commercial lives on in cyberspace.

On Wednesday night, people on the party's e-mail list received a message titled ''Conservative Party's newest TV advertisement,'' which provided a link to the party's Internet site. There, with the click of a button and the right software, visitors can view the ad, which uses the children's game Operation to disparage Mrs. Clinton's failed health care reform effort of 1993.
The Conservative Party may have pulled from the airwaves an ad assailing Hillary Rodham Clinton on health care, but the commercial lives on in cyberspace.

On Wednesday night, people on the party's e-mail list received a message titled ''Conservative Party's newest TV advertisement,'' which provided a link to the party's Internet site. There, with the click of a button and the right software, visitors can view the ad, which uses the children's game Operation to disparage Mrs. Clinton's failed health care reform effort of 1993.

The commercial was taken off the air last month as a result of a deal reached on Sept. 23 between Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic Senate nominee, and Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican nominee, who has been endorsed by the Conservative Party. The agreement prohibits the candidates from using soft money -- largely unregulated, unlimited contributions to political parties -- to broadcast ads, and requires the candidates to urge advocacy groups to do the same.

Michael R. Long, the chairman of the Conservative Party, said yesterday a staff member had sent the message to drum up interest in the party's Web site. He said he did not believe that keeping the commercial on the Web site violated the soft money ban.

Neither the State Democratic Party nor the Republican Party has commercials posted on its Web site. And spokesmen for the candidates did not object to the ad's being posted on the Web site, saying the agreement covered only television and radio.
